title: Seymour Weiss (diplomat)
text:
Seymour Weiss (May 15, 1925 – September 23, 1992) was a <a href="United%20States">United States</a> <a href="diplomat">diplomat</a> and a high-ranking official at the <a href="United%20States%20Department%20of%20State">United States Department of State</a>.
Biography.
Seymour Weiss was born in <a href="Chicago">Chicago</a> in 1925. He served in the <a href="United%20States%20Navy">United States Navy</a> during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, achieving the rank of <a href="Lieutenant">Lieutenant</a>. After the war, he attended the <a href="University%20of%20Pennsylvania">University of Pennsylvania</a>, and then received a <a href="Master%20of%20International%20Affairs">Master of International Affairs</a> degree from the <a href="University%20of%20Chicago">University of Chicago</a>.
Weiss then spent five years working in the <a href="Office%20of%20Management%20and%20Budget">Office of Management and Budget</a> and the <a href="United%20States%20Agency%20for%20International%20Development">United States Agency for International Development</a>. Weiss then joined the <a href="United%20States%20Foreign%20Service">United States Foreign Service</a>.
From 1968 to 1969, Weiss headed the State Department's Office of Strategic Research and Intelligence. He spent 1972-73 as deputy director of the <a href="Policy%20Planning%20Staff%20%28United%20States%29">Policy Planning Staff</a>.
In 1973, <a href="President%20of%20the%20United%20States">President of the United States</a> <a href="Richard%20Nixon">Richard Nixon</a> nominated Weiss as <a href="Director%20of%20the%20Bureau%20of%20Politico-Military%20Affairs">Director of the Bureau of Politico-Military Affairs</a>; he held this office from August 6, 1973 until January 17, 1974.
President <a href="Gerald%20Ford">Gerald Ford</a> appointed Weiss <a href="United%20States%20Ambassador%20to%20the%20Bahamas">United States Ambassador to the Bahamas</a> in 1974, and Weiss held this post, his last, from September 11, 1974 until December 15, 1976.
In retirement, Weiss continued to act as an adviser on foreign policy and defense affairs. In the late 1970s, was an advisor to <a href="Team%20B">Team B</a>. During the <a href="1980%20United%20States%20presidential%20election">1980 presidential election</a>, he was a foreign policy advisor for <a href="Ronald%20Reagan">Ronald Reagan</a>, and during the Reagan administration, he would serve as an advisor to <a href="United%20States%20Secretary%20of%20Defense">United States Secretaries of Defense</a> <a href="Caspar%20Weinberger">Caspar Weinberger</a> (1981–87) and <a href="Frank%20Carlucci">Frank Carlucci</a>, and under the administration of <a href="George%20H.%20W.%20Bush">George H. W. Bush</a> as an advisor to <a href="United%20States%20Secretary%20of%20Defense">Defense Secretary</a> <a href="Dick%20Cheney">Dick Cheney</a>. Weiss was generally considered a <a href="neoconservative">neoconservative</a>, a <a href="War%20Hawk">hawk</a>, and an anti-<a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet</a> hard-liner.
Weiss died of <a href="liver%20cancer">liver cancer</a> at his home in <a href="Bethesda%2C%20Maryland">Bethesda, Maryland</a> on September 23, 1992.
